awd_titl_txt: A New Instrument to Remove the Effects of Interstellar Dust Masking Faint Radiation in the Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
Theories of the early Universe predict a very weak polarization signal in the cosmic microwave background radiation.  However, stronger signals from interstellar clouds and magnetic fields in our Milky Way Galaxy prevent scientists from measuring that faint signal.  The space between the stars contains many such clouds of gas and dust.  Dramatic astronomical images reveal them - for example, the Great Nebula in the constellation Orion or the famous Eagle Nebula.  Dust grains in the interstellar clouds also polarize reflected starlight weakly.  Astronomers can measure this weak polarization in order to find the interstellar clouds.  In this project, the Investigators will construct a novel instrument to measure the optical polarization produced by interstellar dust clouds.  Using these measurements with spacecraft data, they will map the locations of Galactic clouds and magnetic fields. Scientists can then separate their signals from the cosmic microwave background radiation. This project serves the national interest by increasing our knowledge of the early Universe. The Investigators will involve an international team of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs in all aspects of this project, giving it strong Broader Impacts.

The Investigators will design and build a novel wide-area linear optical polarimeter (WALOP) and will use the instrument to measure polarization caused by interstellar dust and to map the distribution of dust in the Milky Way Galaxy.  With a 30 x 30 arcminute field of view, the polarimeter will form four simultaneous images of each star, enabling determinations of the magnitude, fractional polarization, and polarization angle for each object.  It will be deployed on a 1-meter telescope at the South African Astronomical Observatory (SAAO).  Combined with distance measurements from the GAIA spacecraft, the polarization data will enable 3D tomography of the interstellar medium, providing information that may enable scientists to extract the very weak polarization signal expected from the cosmic microwave background (CMB).  The Intellectual Merit of the work derives primarily from the fact that improved mapping of the dust distribution in the Galaxy may enable astronomers to detect a predicted weak polarization signal (the so-called "B-mode" signal) in CMB radiation, significantly improving cosmologists' understanding of the very early Universe.   The observations also will improve astronomers'understanding of dust formation, evolution, composition, and alignment by magnetic fields in the Galaxy. The investigators plan strong programs aimed at undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs at Caltech, at IUCAA in India, at the SAAO, and at the University of Crete in Greece, combining instrument development with cutting-edge astrophysics and cosmology programs and including reciprocal visits among the partner institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The overall aim of this project is to open a new window on the universe by measuring the optical polarization of starlight from about ten million stars over the whole sky in order to determine the strength and orientation of the Galactic magnetic field, and to enable in depth studies of the interstellar medium. No existing polarimeters could undertake this task, so an entirely novel optical polarimeter was developed, called ?RoboPol?, which makes accurate measurements of the polarization of starlight with only one exposure. After the successful deployment of RoboPol, we enhanced the design by incorporating wide-field capability, culminating in the wide-area linear optical polarimeter (WALOP), which is ideally matched to the overall project goals.  The design of the WALOP was completed, and two WALOPs were built.  The hardware required for installation of these two WALOPS, on a 1-m telescope at the South African Astronomical Observatory (SAAO), and on a 1.3-m telescope  at the Skinakas Observatory in Crete, will be completed by the end of June, and these two polarimeters will then be installed on these two dedicated telescopes for the polarimetry survey.

 

The primary motivation for the survey is to facilitate removal of foreground emission arising in our Galaxy from the Cosmic Microwave Background radiation (CMB) arising soon after the Big Bang. The polarization of the CMB carries important information in its "B-mode" about the early state of the Universe and the period of rapid inflation that is believed to have occurred before the formation of the stars, galaxies and other structures that now populate the Universe. The CMB polarization has been measured by the WMAP and Planck satellite missions, but is contaminated by foreground emission from the Galaxy. The WALOP observations will be used to determine the contamination of CMB observations at about 100 GHz where the CMB polarization is most readily detected, and to show that no part of the sky is free from dust contamination at a level sufficient to measure or place useful limits on the B-mode CMB polarization signal. To measure the CMB polarization accurately it is necessary to carefully model and subtract the contaminating signals. This requires measuring the foregrounds at a wide range of frequencies, and WALOP will be essential for tying down the dust part of the foreground contamination.

 

We started taking sparse polarization measurements with RoboPol and an SAAO polarimeter in order to fine tune the survey strategy in terms of parameters like exposure times that will be needed in different parts of the sky based on expected levels of polarizations signal. This will accelerate the wide survey once the instrument is installed. In addition, the sparse observations made with the SAAO polarimeter (called HIPPO), were made for the purpose of identifying zero-polarization fields for calibration. Such calibration fields do not currently exist for the whole sky. Therefore this work will also be published and be used for future instruments. We developed the data analysis tools and pipelines, and are fully prepared to undertake the survey.

 

The WALOP maps will also be important for understanding the structure of the Galactic interstellar medium and magnetic field.  WALOP can measure the magnetic field strength and orientation, using observations of the dust-induced polarization of stars and the distances to the stars obtained from the GAIA satellite mission.  Thus  the WALOPs will provide essential data for understanding the three-dimensional structure of the Galactic magnetic field.
